texts.definition: The ability of players to be able and influence gameplay through gameplay actions or ways of affecting game instances themselves.
markups: <style="Definition">The ability of players to be able and influence gameplay through gameplay actions or ways of affecting game instances themselves.</style>

Basically all games try to give players possibilities to influence the game state and the outcome of game instances. Players that do have this possibility do have <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style>.

All games which allow players to develop clear gameplay mastery can provide <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style>. Examples include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients">Defense of the Ancients</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake 3 Arena</link></style>.

The game masters of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> have great <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> since they can create whole game worlds, can change or make rules, and determine how events should unfold during gameplay.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/4%20Minutes%20and%2033%20Seconds%20of%20Uniqueness">4 Minutes and 33 Seconds of Uniqueness</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Progress%20Quest">Progress Quest</link></style> are examples of games made to not let players have any agency while gameplay progresses. Luck-based gambling games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Baccarat">Baccarat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Craps">Craps</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Roulette">Roulette</link></style> can also be seen as anti-examples of <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style>.

While each case of providing players with actions can be seen as a way of giving player their <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style>, some more abstract patterns can support it well. <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style> in general make players better at actions or move them further through the intended gameplay, and while this may provide <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> they can actually also work against it at the same time on a different level if players have no say in what to get better at or where to move within the possible gameplay. <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> between several different actions is a natural continuation of the idea of giving players actions as is providing <style="Link"><link="framed-freedom">Framed Freedom</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style> can provide players agency in how to develop this over time. However, <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> can be more creative in nature in games by allowing players to develop <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> or by letting them have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>. It can also be given to players through giving them <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, or, rather, they can at least be given the impression of <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style>. <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> can also be given about how gameplay should take place, from allowing <style="Link"><link="negotiable-play-sessions">Negotiable Play Sessions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style> to more generally allowing games to have <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Self-Facilitated%20Rules">Self-Facilitated Rules</link></style> also provide <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> outside gameplay proper by letting players modify or break rules. <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> takes this to an extreme since these can also control the rules of the game.

Some patterns works directly against <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> and should therefore be avoided or considered extra times before used together with it. Examples of these patterns include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="no-direct-player-influence">No Direct Player Influence</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="repetitive-gameplay">Repetitive Gameplay</link></style> also does this when there is no real choices to make, either because they don't exist or because one does not have time to consider them. Other, e.g. <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>, and forced <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>, can be used as <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> that temporarily remove <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style>. <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-game-states">Unwinnable Game States</link></style> works against <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> if players are trying to win a game which makes it non-problematic if players are either not trying to win or if they are playing <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> which provides them with other goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Subjective%20Patterns">Subjective Pattern</link></style> and can therefore result in fickle designs. For example, the use of <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="lucky-guess-solutions">Lucky Guess Solutions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player/System%20Action%20Composites">Player/System Action Composites</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="player-augmentations">Player Augmentations</link></style> can support <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> but just as well work against it if players do not perceive the abilities they have as being under their control.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Player Agency</style> can make players feel that they can affect and at least partially control gameplay, it can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> to them and provide a sense of <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> if they use this agency to affect the game state intentionally.
